instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
Not sure if this is relevant but board came from customer machine that I installed new battery on. This was 3 months ago. They used it two times and on the third time it didn't turn on.

This machine was babied by the owner. The board is super clean, no corrosion, liquid spill or noticeably damaged components.

Tested the charge, it takes 20v and 0.03A. Removed the board and connected to power. Below are the measurements.

USB Meter: 20v 0.03A
20.11v <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
0.002v <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> (F7000, <CAPACITOR>C7051</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> all show the same)
0.002v <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7000)


What do?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Test the board alone on the desk; nothing connected, just USB-C port.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at least (<RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>)?
If not check <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltage.

Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>.

Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
Thank you, I'm excited to be here. ?

The readings above were with the board alone on the desk, nothing connected with just USB-C port charger & USB digital tester.

3.422 <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> @ <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>
20.11 <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on all pins


<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> Voltages:

20.11 <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> (measured <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>)
5.09 VDDA
5.09 VDDP
5.014 <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>
5.09 <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL> (measured <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>)
3.423 <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL> (measured <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL>)
3.423 <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> (measured <SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL>)

For Diode mode do I need to measure all components in that circuit? I measured around 10 for each.
Diode Mode:
2.783 <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
0.7 <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was strange because it would start at 0.8 then down to 0.7, 0.6, 0.5, shut off and then reappear at 2.783k is that normal?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
No need for diode mode at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, if already get proper voltage.
BTW, read how to properly check diode mode.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

Check <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
Just in case, remove F7000 and check <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> voltage.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
I see now. It's meant to check the test points, not the specific components in that circuit. Thank you for that.

3.421 <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

Removed F7000
13.06v <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> 

Computer now takes 20v with 0A compared to 20v with 0.03A

F7000 
13.06v Pin 1
0.00v Pin 2

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
"2.783 <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>"
Read that post carefully.
You cannot get such reading with red probe at ground!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
I remeasured in diode mode. Red probe at ground. Black probe on test point for <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> next to <RESISTOR>R5168</RESISTOR>. No power connected. Board by itself on desk.

2.753

Tried putting red probe on USB-C shield, screw holes, RAM shield, etc. All measured the same 2.753.

Tried black probe on 5-8 components that are on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and all measure the same so far.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
Really strange...
I get 374 in two 00840/75 boards.
Did you check at L6995?
If yes, check if <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is not open.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
Checked L6995.

2.750 Pin 1
2.753 Pin 2

Checked <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> using continuity mode. Beeps. Doesn't look damaged.

2.740 Pin 1
2.743 Pin 2

I have another 00875 board that takes 20v and 0.05A. I checked L6995 in diode mode. ~2.8
00840 board that takes 5.18v with 0.03A and L6995 in diode mode has ~2.7

Can this be a clue?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message: Did you really check in diode mode, or ohm (resistance)?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
This is so embarrassing. ?

I was using resistance. Switching over to diode mode we get 374.

With F7000 still removed I get 0 on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

EDIT: 
Reinstalled F7000. I made sure it was installed by using continuity mode and putting each probe on the opposite pads.

Still get 0 on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> for diode mode.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
"0.7 <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>"
Was this 0hm reading?
0.7 ohm is pure short; 0.700 in diode mode, not at all.
Do you now understand the difference?
You just wasted 2 days with a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

Now check if any big coil gives you the same ohm reading like <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
Yep, I understand now.
0.7 was in Ohms. In diode mode it gives me 0 for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

By big coils are you referring to L7030, L7210, L7220 and other “L” components on the board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v, 0.03A, doesn't power on
threads.message:
Not L7030, as you get voltage on <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR>, when F7000 is removed.
Your problem is after the fuse...
